metadata.case_name: Pursa Ltd. v. Income Tax Authorities

facts.text: Pursa Ltd. incorporated in 1905 under Indian Companies Act, all shareholders and directors residents in United Kingdom, business of growers of sugarcane, manufacturers of sugar and dealers in sugar.
Crushing season for manufacture of sugar is from December to April each year.
Towards end of 1942, attempt made to sell entire business but failed.
In middle of 1943, directors commenced negotiations for sale of factory and other assets with ultimate object of winding up the company.
On 9th August 1943, inventory prepared and firm offer received from Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. for purchase of factory and stores as on that date.
On 16th August 1943, offer communicated by cable to directors in England.
On 20th August 1943, directors asked local managers in India to proceed with matter in anticipation of sanction of shareholders at extraordinary general meeting to be held shortly.
Extraordinary general meeting held on 8th October 1943, firm offer of Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. accepted and concluded agreement for sale came into existence.

On 7th December 1943, written memorandum of agreement executed whereby company agreed to sell to Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. for Rs. 28 lacs all lands, buildings, machinery, plant etc. as on 9th August 1943 subject to subsequent use and consumption in ordinary course of business, excluding stocks of manufactured sugar and grain, and stores bought after that date.
Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. paid Rs. 28 lacs on 7th December 1943 and got possession of factory on 10th December 1943.
On date of sale, company possessed sugar stock valued at Rs. 6 lacs excluded from sale; continued to sell up to June 1944.
Sugar stock excluded because not possible to know sale date and sugar produced in 1943 had to be sold through exclusive selling agents under contract.

Between 9th August 1943 and 10th December 1943, company never used machinery and plant for manufacturing sugar or any other purpose except keeping in trim and running order; throughout accounting period (1st October 1943 to 30th September 1944) machinery and plant not used.
Company went into voluntary liquidation on 20th June 1945; delay due to legal difficulties with transfer of mokarari lands.
Assessment year 1945-46, relevant accounting year 1st October 1943 to 30th September 1944.
Income-tax Officer letter dated 21st February 1947 to liquidators asking why activities not treated as realisation of assets on impending liquidation rather than carrying on business.
Liquidators reply dated 19th March 1947: company in liquidation from 20th June 1945, disagree not carrying on business in 1944, debits incurred in carrying on business.
Income-tax Officer letter dated 17th May 1947 claiming profits on sale of machinery and plant taxable under second proviso to section 10(2)(vii), surplus Rs. 13,05,144.
Liquidators reply dated 22nd May 1947: profits not taxable as arising from ceasing to carry on business.
Income-tax Officer order dated 21st June 1947 held profits assessable under section 10(2)(vii), added Rs. 13,05,144.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed appeal on 30th January 1947 [note: likely 1948].
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal by order dated 17th May 1949 in I.T.A. No. 147 of 1948-49.
Tribunal referred two questions to High Court under section 66(1).

Patna High Court: Shearer J. negative to both questions; Sarjoo Prasad J. affirmative to both; Ramaswami J. agrees with Sarjoo Prasad on first, Shearer on second; majority: first affirmative (against assessee), second negative.
High Court declined certificate for appeal; Supreme Court granted special leave.

legal_issues.text: On the facts and in the circumstances of this case is the surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery of the sugar factory chargeable under section 10(2)(vii)?
Was the profit of Rs. 15,882 on the sale of stores of the factory taxable under the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of this case?

petitioner_arguments.text: Profits on sale of machinery and plant were not profits arising from a business carried on by the company but were profits arising from the company ceasing to carry on business.
Company had gone into liquidation on 20th June 1945 and was carrying on business during the year ended 30th September 1944; debits in sugar factory accounts incurred in carrying on business.

respondent_arguments.text: Company's activities during previous year amount to realisation of assets on impending liquidation rather than carrying on business.
Company carrying on business up to date of sale of machinery (7th December 1943); sale of machinery part of carrying on business.
Sugar stocks not sold on 7th December 1943 purposely to sell to best advantage later; business carried on subsequent to sale of machinery, substantial expenses incurred.

court_reasoning.text: Tax payable under section 10(1) only in respect of profits or gains of business carried on by assessee; business implies continuous exercise of activity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits assessable only from business actually carried on.

court_reasoning.text: Second proviso to section 10(2)(vii) deems excess of sale proceeds over written down value to be profits only for machinery or plant used for purposes of the business; 'used' means at least for part of accounting year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Machinery and plant not used at all during accounting year.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal misdirected itself on meaning of section 10; overlooked that machinery not used in accounting year; findings of fact inconclusive and cannot support decision.
If sale part of carrying on business, assessable under section 10(1); if under proviso, not real profits of business carried on.

holdings.text: Surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 not chargeable under section 10(2)(vii) as machinery and plant not used for purposes of business in accounting year.

precedents_cited.relevance: Fundamental idea of business is continuous exercise of activity; critical words 'carried on by him' essential for taxable income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Fraser
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can intervene if tribunal misunderstands statutory language or makes finding without evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax on profits of business carried on; allowances including depreciation and balancing charge on sale of used machinery; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal on the first question, holding that the surplus from sale of plant and machinery is not chargeable under section 10(2)(vii) as the assets were not used in the business during the accounting year. No appeal on second question.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed in favour of assessee on first question.

key_quotes.text: "the machinery or plant must be such as were used, in whatever sense that word is taken, at least for a part of the accounting year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability of section 10(2)(vii) proviso.

key_quotes.text: "the entire decision of the tribunal was vitiated by its failure to keep in view the true meaning and scope of section 10(2)(vii)"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Business is defined by section 2(4) as including any trade, commerce or manufacture, or any adventure or concern in the nature of trade, commerce or manufacture."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of taxable business activity.
